author: Staff Reporter
text:
Around 2,000 members of Joint Action Committee of Tamil Nadu Teacher’s Organisation (JACTTO), a confederation of around 20 schoolteachers’ associations in the State, lay siege to the Collector’s office on Monday, the last day of their three-day State-wide protest to press for their 15-point charter of demands.

Police sources said that 1,400 of those who participated in the protest were women. As they did in the last two days, the City Police detained all the protesting teachers and released them later in the evening.

The key demands of the teachers included increase in their pay as per the Sixth Pay Commission recommendation on a par with teachers of Central government schools, removal of Contributory Pension Scheme (CPS) and restoration of the old pension scheme.

Their demands also included appointment of a special officer in every high and higher secondary school to execute the 14 welfare schemes of Tamil Nadu government, which included distribution of free laptops, text books and uniforms. JACTTO members said that headmasters and teachers were being utilised for carrying out these welfare schemes, thereby jeopardising the primary duty of teaching.

JACTTO had also demanded regularisation of pay for teachers who were appointed on contractual and consolidated pay basis during 1986-1988 and 2004-2006 respectively.
title: JACTTO continues protest for third day
